Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Performance Limits of Multi-hop MIMO Networks via Tractable Models and Optimization

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to close the gap between rapid advances at the multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) physical layer by the wireless communications research community and current limited progress on MIMO by the networking research community. The proposed approach is to develop simple and accurate models for multi-hop MIMO networks and, based on such new models, to advance fundamental understanding of such networks. The research tasks include: (1) the development of new simple and accurate models beneath the network layer; (2) the exploration of performance optimization for multi-hop MIMO networks; and (3) the design of distributed cross-layer algorithms that can approach optimal solutions.

This project serves a critical need in the research community by producing new models beneath the network layer that are both tractable and accurate. The findings of this project will remove the current barrier facing multi-hop MIMO network research and allow the research community to fully understand the potential of such networks. Based on these findings, new knowledge frontiers for multi-hop MIMO networks can be explored that were once considered difficult; and new insights and discoveries (possibly unexpected) are now possible.

The education plan of this project is to develop new cross-disciplinary teaching materials for wireless networking, with the goal of closing the knowledge gap between networking and wireless communications. This project will involve undergraduates and under-represented students in wireless networking research, with the goal of building their future careers in networking related fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A critical factor affecting the wide-scale deployment of wireless ad hoc networks is network capacity. Recent advances in multiple-input-multiple-out (MIMO) technology show that much higher spectrum efficiency and capacity gain can be achieved by the use of multiple antennas at a node. Although many research advances of MIMO at the physical layer or for single-hop wireless communications have been made, fundamental understanding of multi-hop MIMO networks remains primitive. The main problem in this research stagnation, as it is now well recognized, is the lack of accurate and tractable MIMO models beneath the network layer that are suitable for analysis by the networking research community. The goal of this project is to establish tractable and accurate models for multi-hop MIMO networks and, based on such new models, to gain fundamental understanding of such networks through exploring their performance limits.  

There are a number of milestones and highlights from our research. In our paper titled “A DoF-based link layer model for multi-hop MIMO networks” (IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, vol. 13, no. 7, July 2014), we developed a tractable link layer DoF (degree-of-freedom) model for multi-hop MIMO networks. We showed that under the assumption of no dependency cycle, this model includes all the feasible solutions by the matrix-based model under spatial multiplexing (SM) and interference cancellation (IC) for any network topology. This work offers an important building block for theoretical research on multi-hop MIMO networks. In our paper titled “Joint Flow Routing and DoF Allocation in Multi-hop MIMO Networks” (IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications, vol. 15, no. 3, March 2016), we employed the new DoF IC model that we developed to study a throughput maximization problem in a multi-hop MIMO network. Given the multi-hop network environment, the problem formulation involves joint consideration of multi-path flow routing at network layer and DoF allocation per node at link layer. Despite the problem formulation is in the form of a mixed-integer linear program, we showed that it is possible to develop an efficient polynomial time algorithm to get a near-optimal solution.  In our paper titled “A Scheduling Algorithm for MIMO DoF Allocation in Multi-hop Networks” (IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, vol. 15, no. 2, February 2016), we studied the question whether the global ordering in the new DoF model can be achieved among the nodes in the network through distributed operations. Through an actual network throughput maximization problem, we showed that it is possible to develop an algorithm that only requires local operations.  Further, we proved that the resulting DoF scheduling solution is globally feasible and showed that there exists a corresponding feasible global node ordering for IC, albeit such global ordering is implicit.  

The contributions from this research to the wireless networking discipline are significant. We observe that existing matrix-based models for MIMO are too mathematically complex.  On the other hand, the current DoF-based models are either overly optimistic (leading to infeasible solutions) or overly conservative (loss of DoF region).  This research serves a critical need in advancing multi-hop MIMO network research by exploring new MIMO DoF models that are both tractable and feasible.  Based on the new MIMO DoF models, we offer network-level understanding of MIMO ad hoc networks via a unified research program consisting of exploring theoretical limits through network optimization and the development of distributed algorithms. This research closes the gap between rapid advances at the MIMO physical layer by the wireless communications research community and current limited progress on MIMO by the networking research community. This research is novel as it involves new ideas that address key limitations with the existing models. New knowledge frontiers for a MIMO ad hoc network can now be explored; a new knowledge boundary may now be defined; and new insights and discoveries are now possible.

This project has offered research and education opportunities to a group of graduate students.  These students came to the project with diverse background from electrical engineering and computer science.  They have gained valuable experience in bridging the gap between networking and wireless communications through the cross-disciplinary approaches that we employed in the investigation. Another important outcome of this project is the development of new cross-disciplinary course materials for wireless networking.  We have published a textbook titled “Applied Optimization Methods for Wireless Networks” (Cambridge University Press, 2014), which offers a set of powerful tools to address complex problems arising from future wireless networks.
